content.description: Nice face to bolt, through roof.
content.protection: Standard Rack. one bolt. no anchors
content.location: This route is on the left detached pillar, not the iceberg proper, facing the approach trail. Starts to the left of the 8' ledge with the cave and tree on it.

content.description: Climb through several roof on big juggy holds, finish in the shallow corner.
content.protection: A single rack of cams should be plenty, chain anchors
content.location: As the name implies...the start is just on the left edge of the corridor as you enter.

content.description: Start on ledge right of WV Clambake.  Climb finger crack/right facing flake up to the right side of large roof. An airy move will gain access to the flake/crack up and left.  Take this to the top.
content.protection: you have to climb above your gear at the crux, so place good gear where the initial crack ends. Top out to find anchors with rings.
content.location: This route starts on ledge to the right of Clambake.  It follows the S shaped line of the large sassafras tree that is directly behind the route.

content.description: Nice short route with a small overhang.
content.protection: Two bolted anchors on top. You need about 3-4 cams
content.location: Route is located between the Iceberg Area and the White Wall. If you walk from the Iceberg Area to the White Wall it's the first route with bolted anchors

content.description:
Blunt arete with (3 bolts) to a two bolt anchor on front side of iceberg.  Start on right side of low roof and climb up left angling ramp/flake. you can place nuts here as first bolt is at top of this feature.  Climb arete past first bolt then step right at 2nd bolt to face.  climb face past 3rd bolt to two bolt anchor with rap rings.

there is an erroneous bolt with no hanger on the optional boulder problem direct start through roof (5.9+).

This route now has 5 bolts. Two bolts were added to make this a sport route; as it seems the newer generation of climbers have no nuts
content.protection: med stoppers, 5 bolts to anchors with rings.
content.location: Front side of iceburg as you approach the cliff.  rappel via fixed slings on tree or off shuts at top of chuck's route.

content.description: Follow the crack system
content.protection: nuts and cams to fist size.  Anchors with rings.
content.location: 25 feet to the right of the entrance to the iceberg corridor.

content.description: Climb up the flakes.
content.protection: Hollow sounding flacks down low, but the protection gets better near the top. Run out the top (about 10 feet) on easy 4th class terrain.

content.description: Nice finger crack.
content.protection: Standard rack, shares anchors with Icecapdes
content.location: It is on the far left tip of the Iceberg proper, looking at it as you come up the trail. Walk down the Corridor between the Iceberg and the main wall, The start is under the little cave on your left near the ledge with the big tree.

content.description: The right hand bolt line in the corridor behind the Iceberg. Goes up vertical face through crimpy edges.
content.protection: 4 bolts to glue-in anchors with rings.

content.description: Also known as: Kill Whitey. Start under overhang just left of Phat Back.  Climb a hard boulder problem straight up to the ledge on the left.  At this point KP crack will be just to your left.  Climb up the white face of the Iceburg on incipient thin cracks to the right of KP Crack.  Tricky and Entertaining!
content.protection: mostly small cams and wires. Shares new anchors with KP Crack.
content.location: This route starts right at the top of the main trail when you get to the Iceburg.

content.description: Start in right facing corner on the Iceberg. Move up and left off roof and up face. Really fun route
content.protection: Standard rack, anchors at the top

content.description: Start left of Tip of the Iceberg, work up the arete and move around left, up through a flake to a ledge and then top of the iceberg.
content.protection: There's a good horizontal on the right side about 7 feet up for the first piece (tricam or red/gray alien), no anchor, standard rack

content.description: Start under roof.  Stem the flair to a mantle.  Continue up the small crack through the second roof.
content.protection: Accepts small pro.  No anchors, use a tree.
content.location: First route when walking from the Iceburg to the White Wall.  Left of Bozippity.

content.description:
Climb up the easy 5.6 budge and gain a ledge. From this ledge lay back into the dihedral and climb up past a roof. From the ground this route doesn't look that interesting but contains interesting movement, and getting over the roof is pretty fun, but a little pumpy.

If you know the 'real' name and grade of this climb , post it on the bottom and I'll updated it.
content.protection: I think this route could be lead. The gear is a little funky and suboptimal from protecting you from hitting the large ledge (if it hold you'll be okay). You can plug micro cams near the top and in the roof before topping out, these placements seem solid, but small.
content.location: Just right of Inflatable forearms on the main cliff line.

content.description: This is a nice little route that is easy to overlook.  Climb thin cracks (crux) up the nice face to a ledge.  Climb up then step left to top.
content.protection: stnd Bozoo rack
content.location: just downstream and around the corner from the start of WV Clambake.

content.description:
Low Start on a diagonal about a foot or two above the small cave to the right. Traverse left on low feet before throwing a high hand on the ledge above you (its better in the back of the ledge) and throw a high foot to the chest high ledge on your left mantle up and grab the line of jugs leading out to the right. You could follow the crack line left but that has no definite finish and puts you in the 20+ foot fall range as the ground slopes away. Either way the grade would likely stay the same. Simple and fun little route open to variation and to the height described stays dry in the rain. Which is how we found the route in the first place.

Anyway thought Id throw this up as a fun route for rainy days or in between routes if you're the odd man out.
content.protection: One Pad is fine two would be nice.  if you fall try and go to your butt fast as the pad will slide so trying to land standing either sends you jogging down the slope or crashes you back anyway so better to just go for it.  A spotter is always nice too.
content.location: This route is found in the small cave behind P-7.  If you walk in from Barking Spiders and walk into the cave look to your left for a left leaning crack line coming down the middle of the wall to a small ledge. That ledge is 3/4 of the way up the problem.  Im sure people have done something in this area but never named anything so try not to take the FA too seriously its a V0-1.  Anyway very fun if you get caught by the rain and want something to do.  I figured this had to start a trad route but haven't seen anything so have at it.

content.description: Climb thin rock up face.
content.protection: small stoppers & small TCUs.  pro gets a little better as you get higher.  Glue-in anchors with rings.
content.location: This route starts 10' left of Barking Spiders.

climbs.name: Chucks Route
climbs.fa: First climbed and bolted by Chuck Gentry.Helped by his dad Wayne.

content.description: Pretty sustained sidepulls and gastons up the the second bolt. The runout from 2-3 looks bad, but isnt. There is a great jug to clip off off. Easy climbing past bolt 3.
content.protection: Three bolts to anchors with rings.
content.location: This is the last route on the left as you look into the corridor. On the berg itself.

content.description: Right leaning hand crack to ledge.  Finish roof to 2 bolt anchors.
content.protection: Small to medium pro (fingers to thin hands).  2 bolt anchor
content.location: Second route when walking from the Iceburg to the White Wall. Right of green carpet. If you get to the detached fin, you've gone too far.

climbs.name: Barking Spiders
climbs.fa: First climbed and bolted by Chuck Gentry.With his dad Wayne.

content.description: The left of the two bolted routes in the corridor not on the iceberg. Start a little right and work up and left. Crux near bolt two.
content.protection: 2 bolts, don't hit the ground, toprope anchors
